title: Roadmap
text: Build document visualisation method alignment Function identify critical/overlapping pathways Create wrapper function around MicrobiomeFunction allows easy import relevant sources, including: SBML (Cobra CarveMe) JSON (COMETS, Escher) YAML (Misosoup). needs : accept factor variables species metabolite, allow flexible variable naming, generate community name missing Write set functions slots Write output methods different formats

title: Roadmap
text: Graph Plotting method Plotting functions EDA info different metabolites/reactions ### MicrobiomeFunctionSet Plotting functions EDA info different communities ### MicrobiomeFunctionAlignment visualise alignment? Read cooccurrence paper see plotting solutions might make sense.

title: Roadmap
text: accessor method produced/consumed species, implementation getMet additional arg = “consumed”/“produced” additional one species. calculate effective fluxes find longest pathway methods common graph metrics ### MicrobiomeFunctionSet MF object, additional argument “community” select one within set. show method includes number communities, average/min/max size terms taxonomy metabolites ### MicrobiomeFunctionAlignment show levels alignment Compare connected vs unconnected alignment get scores different alignment get alignments including certain species metabolites

title: Roadmap
text: Make methods quicker including alignments cut limit write search function either takes MF object name MF object MFS search closest relative . Toggle connected disconnected alignment Improve speed Warning aligning MF ID minimum flux production used alignment Percent Identity (improve speed ) return (dis-) connected modules connectedness alignment (compared connectedness reactions?) centrality edge alignment make method takes min number reactions alignment, argument threshold cutoff depth alignment completley connected, evaluate connectedness level alignment. pairwise vs multiple alignment? Return metric average length reactions alignment? peripheral vs central communities alignment? solved making big graph communities giving node groups communities ’s . group average centrality good measure. introduce gaps alignment? easily done introducing placeholder metabolites/species. best way go ? Matrix multiplication graph representation? introduce option align without gaps argument gaps = TRUE/FALSE maximum connected breadth can achieve set communities? –> gaps useful .

text: Can performance improved switching use databases? Reread hypergraph paper consider implications

title: Algorithms
text: identity matrix given non-redundant count reactions given level alignment count reactions set consortia. BM = binary matrix representing edges set consortia ∑BM−(∑<jA(2)(,j)+(N))−(∑<j<kA(3)(,j,k)+(N)) \sum \text{BM} - \left( \sum_{< j} ^{(2)}(,j)  + ^{(N)} \right) - \left( \sum_{< j < k} ^{(3)}(,j,k)  + ^{(N)} \right) score compare tanimoto coefficient?

title: MicrobiomeFunction Class
text: MicrobiomeFunction (MF) objects build backbone fsmc functionality providing novel approach representation microbial consortia functional perspective. one three main object types fsmc. MicrobiomeFunction class serves standard way save work data metabolism, function, microbial community.

title: MicrobiomeFunction Class
text: Upon creation MicrobiomeFunction class based three column input, additional information calculated: graph representation network MiCo object data different matrices weights graph purely directional, disable calculations bin_mat can define optimised / generalist / robust consortia? metrics object? Tanimoto? MES score (relationship consumption production metabolites) SCS, MUS, MPS, MIP/MRO, SMETANA species metabolites fluxes edges binary matrix flux matrix name flux_consumption flux_production effective_flux_consumption effective_flux_production slots described MicrobiomeFunction-class() class documentation.

title: MicrobiomeFunction Class
text: unkown metabolites database ChemmineR 0 fluxes input data correct column names Need function calcs phylo tree metabolites Return output different issues input data

title: MicrobiomeFunction Class
text: Create unnamed matrix save metabolite names col/row data

title: MicrobiomeFunction Class
text: getCo(): Returns community tibble format. getSpecies(): Retrieves species community. getMet(): Retrieves metabolites community. getFlux(): Retrieves fluxes community. getEdges(): Retrieves edges community.

title: MicrobiomeFunction Class
text: create object type MiCo, user must input data listed . data can either contained single tibble data frame, saved CSV file, input separate vectors. species: character vector specifying species present community. met: character vector specifying metabolites present community. flux: numeric vector specifying fluxes metabolite community. name: Character string giving name community. fsmc provides function syn_community() generate random MiCo objects based user parameters.
code: data <- tibble::tibble(   species = c("RQR9693L", "RQR9693L", "RQR9693L", "RQR9693L", "MEV1152G", "MEV1152G", "MEV1152G", "XIQ2234Q", "XIQ2234Q", "XIQ2234Q"),   met = c("met3", "met1", "met4", "met4", "met3", "met2", "met2", "met3", "met4", "met1"),   flux = c(-0.3023640, 0.5344641, -2.2337716, 3.3063823, 2.5520278, 0.3388498, -1.8460633, -1.3043675, -0.4788769, 0.6027292)  )  # MicrobiomeFunction(data, name = "example_MiCo") # makeSynMiCo(n_species = 8, max_met = 10, name = "example_syn_MiCo")

what: Create a MiCo Object from a tibble
title: MicrobiomeFunction Class
text: fsmc contains set example data can used analysis microbial communities. example, use data created MiSoS(oup). Two example communities provided package ac_A1R12_1 cit_A1R12_1. MiCo function can take either path .csv file data frame/tibble input.

title: MicrobiomeFunctionAlignment Class
text: Clarify Alignment represented primarily. also TSE object? use assays store alignment, allow quick calculation depth breadth well. Decide metrics include alignment many communities given species? go multiscale entropy? maximise community overlap alignment? happens completley disconnected grpahs? align without gaps? extent alignment interactive? Takes number MicrobiomeFunction objects input (? list …) additional argument specify pairwise alignment communities desired. default align communities pairwise = TRUE unique pairwise combinations aligned. alignment calculated upon creation object calculated demand?

title: MicrobiomeFunctionAlignment Class
text: variety methods can called MicrobiomeFunctionAlignment object. output methods assigned back variable containing object persist. clusterAlignment: Takes MicrobiomeFunctionAlignment object input additional argument specify clustering algorithm used, works MicrobiomeFunctionAlignment objects undergone pairwise alignment.

title: MicrobiomeFunctionAlignment Class
text: value gives scalar value represent identity two communities. α∑=1n(∑Ci−α)+α \frac{\alpha}{\sum\limits_{= 1}^{n}(\sum C_i - \alpha) + \alpha}

title: MicrobiomeFunctionAlignment Class
text: Communities hash/list containing MicrobiomeFunction objects overall alignment matrix (binary) alignment matrix longest connected components level score alignments communities highly? figure connecctedness parts alignment whicch less communities represented overall alignment?

title: MicrobiomeFunctionSet
text: MFS can created uniting number MF objects together calling MicrobiomeFunctionSet() MFS() either list MF objects inidividual MF objects. process self trigger processing data, thing happens metadata MFS calculated UUID generated. upon creation, mode alignment already known can supplied constructor function MF follows: MicrobiomeFunctionSet(…, alignment=“multiple”)

Functions to Change the orientation of MiCo Input Data — pivotMF
text: tb Tibble data microbial community long short format species Column name species column name column specifying met consumed name column specifying met excreted flux Column name flux column

title: Functions to Change the orientation of MiCo Input Data — pivotMF
code: tb <- tibble::tribble(   ~uptake, ~secretion, ~flux, ~species,   "m1", "m2", 1, "s1",   "m2", "m3", 1, "s2",   "m3", "m4", 1, "s3",   "m4", "m1", 1, "s4" )  pivotMF(   tb = tb,   species = "species",   from = "uptake",   to = "secretion",   flux = "flux" ) #> # A tibble: 8 × 3 #>   species met    flux #>   <chr>   <chr> <dbl> #> 1 s1      m1       -1 #> 2 s1      m2        1 #> 3 s2      m2       -1 #> 4 s2      m3        1 #> 5 s3      m3       -1 #> 6 s3      m4        1 #> 7 s4      m4       -1 #> 8 s4      m1        1
